awd_titl_txt: Mechanics and Kinetics of Void Swelling in Irradiated Nanoporous Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a significant demand for the discovery of advanced materials that can survive high temperature and high-dose radiations for next generation nuclear reactors. Under these operating conditions, a large number of metallic materials develop voids that result in embrittlement and consequent failure. Void swelling occurs as radiation induces atomic defects that migrate elsewhere leaving clusters of vacant positions behind. These vacancy clusters form voids and grow continuously. The principal investigators' initial study shows just the opposite phenomenon, however: that is, voids in metals with existing nanoscale pores shrink rather than expand during radiation. This research will investigate this phenomenon and may add radically to the understanding of fundamental mechanisms of radiation damage mitigation. A positive outcome will enhance the design of radiation tolerant nanoporous materials for advanced nuclear energy systems. In this project, special effort will be made to recruit female and other minority students. Additionally, collaborations with scientists at Argonne National Laboratories and Los Alamos National Laboratory will offer graduate students summer research experience at premier national labs. 

The goal of this project is to understand, via a combination of modeling and experiments, the fundamental mechanisms through which deliberately introduced nanovoids in nanoporous metallic materials can absorb and eliminate radiation induced point defects, and ultimately curtail void swelling significantly and alleviate radiation embrittlement. The innovative concepts put forward here are the possibility of utilizing nanovoids and their stress field to trap, store and annihilate various defect species associated with radiation damage, and restore the capability to absorb defects continuously. Furthermore, nanoporous metals may have enhanced plasticity in comparison to radiation embrittlement frequently observed in bulk fully-dense counterparts. This study integrates in situ radiation experiments with phase field modeling to investigate the kinetics of void swelling, and combine in situ nanomechanical testing with dislocation dynamics modeling to explore mechanics and plasticity of irradiated nanoporous metals.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project is to investigate the mechanisms through which deliberately introduced nanovoids in nanoporous (NP) metallic materials can absorb and eliminate radiation induced point defects (interstitials and vacancies) and curtail void swelling. The ultimate goal is to provide design guidelines for an appropriate distribution of nanovoids with different size and density to trap, store and annihilate various defect species associated with radiation damage, and restore the capability to absorb defects continuously. The investigators combine experiments and phase field simulations to perform the following major tasks: (1) explore the size effect of nanopores/nanovoids on void swelling resistance via a combination of in situ heavy ion irradiation and phase field simulation; (2) investigate the temperature dependence of void evolution in NP metals, which will allow the evaluation of thermal and radiation stability of nanovoids; (3) understand the fundamental mechanisms of how stress fields surrounding nanovoids can affect defect migration kinetics and associate with the temperature dependent void morphology evolution via phase field modeling. This project brings the concept of design of novel radiation tolerant materials for advanced nuclear energy applications by using nanovoids to the materials community. The combination of in situ irradiation and phase field simulation advance our understanding of the fundamental mechanisms of free surface mitigated radiation damage.

 

Intellectual merit. The major scientific findings of this NSF project can be summarized as follows. (1) Discovered that single Kr ion irradiation resulted in nanovoid shrinkage due to the net flux of interstitials into the voids through combination of in situ radiation and phase field simulations. (2) Revealed that He pre-injection suppressed void shrinkage. (3) Atomistic simulations revealed the existence of He removes SFT completely leaving behind clusters of helium atoms. (4) Fluctuations of void sizes during in situ irradiation of Cu at high temperature was observed enabled by a convolutional neural network with greedy matching to detect and track nanovoid evolutions and migrations. (5) Discovered the impact of nanovoids and nanotwin networks on mechanical properties of Cu.

 

Broader impact. (a) Outreach to scientific community. During this NSF project, we collaborated with scientists from Los Alamos National Laboratory. (b) Dissemination of results to broader audience. The PIs’ teams from Purdue University hosted numerous undergraduate students in consecutive years and involved them in this project. (c) Professional preparation for students. 3 Ph.D. students were directly involved in this project, and one of them is a female student and has joined National lab as a postdoc. Another student will become a faculty in Hongkong. (d) Research outcome. 18 articles were published in peer-reviewed scientific journals, including an invited review article. Numerous invited talks were presented at national and international conferences and national laboratories.

 


Last Modified: 10/02/2022
Modified by: Xinghang Zhang
